title: This game started with 4 bans for 40 champions
body:
Since around 70 champs, we've had 6 bans.

Now we have over 130 champs, and still only those 6 bans.  I'm not even going to remark on the balance issues and number of strong champions; there are simply too many champions to ban, and not enough bans to handle it.

Would 1 ban per player be too much to ask in Ranked/Draft?

replies.body:
The problem is that with more bans is that it doesn't fix any problems.  When you look at the data, some champions are banned even though they aren't pivotal to winning or losing a game.  They are merely perceived as being a pain in the butt and no one wants to deal with them.

Why do I ban Blitz?  It's not because he's strong, it's because his pull is so annoying that when I support I don't want to play against it.  If I didn't ban him, would their team automatically win?  No, not at all, I could counter with morgana or just not get pulled.  But I don't want to deal with it.

On the flip side, there are champions that are more powerful than others, and they are usually either picked or banned in any game.  If we allowed the possibility for more of these champs to get banned, would that fix the problem?  Probably not, since the next-most-OP champ would become the new standard, and nothing has really changed.

I disagree with you.

Saying because the next in line op thing would be the new problem is such a lazy argument.
The only thing that's an argument for is that rito's balance team sucks dick.

The thing with bans is you actually get to ban stuff you dont want to deal with. like you said not only op champs get banned so that there is a counter to ur own argument, brilliant really.

I dont want to deal with these stupid guinso vaynes on my team so i ban the champ, is it op maybe? i don't know all i see tho is someone farming jungle for 30 minutes with the few ganks happening ending in disaster. And when it finally has the core build shes 0/11/2 while were defending our nexus turrets.

I also do not want to deal with lucian ekko and graves, and id like to ban malzahar if im not playing him, not to mention azir is also a pain in the butt to play against.

I would probably need 10 bans just for myself, and i imagine the same goes for most players, except all we ask for is just 1 ban each.

Will it magically solve everything? NO!
Will it help alleviate at least some frustration? HELL YES!!

Another reason why 1 ban each is a good thing is because currently pick #1 and #2 both don't get to ban, and they are first/second pick. Kind of sucks that the people who get to ban are the people who already can counter react to the other teams choices. With all the new added champs at least give us more bans, in this S6 of pick of ban the op champs.

The argument that you're going to ban champions that are just a annoying and not inherently broken doesn't actually help your cause whatsoever. The only reason a champion should be logically banned is if they are game-breakingly broken. Other than that, being able to ban "annoying" champions is a luxury. (Edit: also, banning can serve to ban champions that counter your team comp, but that still doesn't mean you should be allowed to literally ban any champion that would pose a challenge to your game).

Most people find every new champ annoying at some point, that doesn't mean we should have infinite bans..

I agree with the other comment that it's unfair that first and second picks don't get bans when they're the ones easily countered. Riot should instead have the first, second, and third players ban champions. It would make more sense that way anyways, by that doesn't mean they should give more bans in general anyways. 

The champion pool is always expanding and that doesn't mean we should get one ban for every ten champions. There are a decent amount of champions that are out of the meta now and only a handful that are even played enough that they'd be a necessary ban.

I swear, people complaining to increase ban count are the same people who must be complaining to increase the amount of refunds were given. Be lucky you have them at all, don't constantly ask for more.

Using the argument that bans should only be used for inherently broken things makes no sense.

Bans are a part of the strategy of the game.  If there is anything that is so inherently broken it needs to be banned every game, than the champion should be disabled.  

You can build strategies around assuming that certain champions won't be in a game, or decide to try a more uncommon strategy by making sure your counter won't be in the game.  

Having more bans would likely expand the meta.  When you have so many high priority picks that they essentially become pick or ban status, people are forced to play them just to ensure the other team doesn't.   If you were able to ban out all of those, lesser played champs would be by default get played more, and you would end up with a lot more variety in the game.
Then why not give everyone 1 ban to deal with 1 less thing that they hate?

The guy didn't even talk about 'strong' champions or what people banned. He merely point out the proportion of bans to champions in game at launch, and again when the bans were raised to 6 as compared to now. With the precedent of raising bans the first time, Riot should still be open to raising the bans again, and the last time was based on numbers of champions in game, not number of 'OP' champs. 

If we had more bans, you would have a better chance at getting to ban Blitz. If you dislike playing against him so much this should be a good thing for you. This goes for any other champ that players dislike seeing in game. More bans = better chance for something you dislike getting banned out. 

If I were to take your final argument seriously, I could take it a step further and say that we should reduce or remove bans. If bans just change the number of 'OP' champs, then we may as well not have the bans to begin with. If League is balanced well, no bans wouldn't really change anything just like adding more won't either.

For reference, Smite has 76 gods in their game, but this season they upped their bans to 4 for each team, 8 total. This change allows players to more easily ban out counter strategies to their team comps, or at the very least allows each lane and jungle a personal ban (assuming team coordination). They have about 60 less playable characters then League does, but they get more bans. That doesn't really seem to make sense to me.
If everyone got to ban the champion they hated most, guaranteed that kench would/could never be played.
If that were true (and he doesnt even come close to my hate-list) then he needs a rework. Same would be true of anyone else that would be true of
I merely used Kench because he's a commonly hated champion. People ban silly things.
I main kench and can use it without problems in rankeds (low-elo)

There's one specific issue with this argument.  The 'next-most-op champ' is the next most op for a reason, because they aren't as op as what was banned.  By forcing the enemy team to pick that champ instead, you are still overall weakening them and making them more manageable.

If your bans are used for the purpose of reducing power overhead, then the number of bans is irrelevent.
Bans apply to both teams. So it isn't just the enemy team that gets limited to the next OP. And if both teams are limited to "the next OP", the the net change is 0.
Granted, there are a ***few*** exceptions that warp the playing field disproportionately (release Xin, Release Fiora, Release rework Mord, etc.), but they are few and far enough between that *increasing* bans still has no effective impact.
the difference between the most op and average is much greater than the next most op and average.

It doesn't matter how big that gap is. Bans affect both teams. If the only goal of your bans is to remove top level power, then you end up in the same effective place.
Remove the top 10 champs from the game, and people will complain that the next 10 are OP. Increasing bans doesn't solve, or even address, this issue (With the rare exception).

If you're banning only to get rid of the strongest champions, then the bans offer no *net gain*. Because all you do is move the bar. Therefore, *more* bans will still have the *same* effect.

Not even close to true.  More bans brings the power level of champions closer together provided, as the argument has been laid out, that we are banning to get rid of the strongest champions.  They follow a rough bell curve centered right around ~50% winrate.  The further out you go, the less champions there are.  They are not equally distributed.  So, if you ban the strongest outliers, the relative power of the champions left to pick becomes closer and closer to one-another; unless someone picks a really low winrate champion and gimps their team by extending the inequality in the opposite direction.

one massive, huge flaw: 

[http://champion.gg/statistics/#?sortBy=general.banRate&order=descend](http://champion.gg/statistics/#?sortBy=general.banRate&order=descend)

Now, Malzahar is a bit of an outlier. But aside from him, look at the most banned champions and compare that to their winrate. 

People arent banning the strongest champions, or at least, they arent banning the champions with the highest winrates.

I personally ban champions that I don't like to play against. I don't care about what other playes ban. We all need bans for ourselves not for "community". If commmunity bans worthless champions - it's not my problem. But if I can't ban champion that I need to ban - it's a problem.

Uh, how do you figure?  The larger the gap is, the more that gap matters.  If I am playing Vladimir (~40-41% winrate) and I am playing against a champion with a 55% winrate, there is a gargantuan difference in power level of our respective champions.  A 53% winrate champion, for example, would cut that gap by 13%.

You clearly don't understand what you are talking about.  Bringing down the power level of outliers does, in fact, make the game more balanced by lowering the discrepancy between the champions used. 

Furthermore, if  every champion with an above 50% winrate was banned, and then everyone was then to choose the next most powerful champions for their role, they would likely all choose champions at the 50% winrate margin.  You know what that would mean?  The rough power level of all of the champions would be many fold closer to eachother than 10 champions in the 50-55% winrate band.

Just because people would shift their complaints does not mean the power difference between champions wouldn't change-- I don't even understand how such an argument would even occur to anyone.  Nominal power level =/= real power level just because people whine and bitch.

{{champion:223}} {{champion:429}} {{champion:203}} {{champion:245}} What do they have in common? Theyre among the last 10 champs released, and have all had serious balance issues needing multiple nerfs and seeing high ban rates.

Once we hit 150 champs, we will be at the point where the "new overloaded 3 passive champs" will have been in the dumpster for over a year, and Warwick and Urgot will still have no update in sight.

The game doesnt have 130 champs, it has choices. Strong, or weak and more weak choices than strong. Riot needs to really start getting their balance team functioning. Bans wouldnt be as important if they didnt rework, or buff champs in such a way that they shoot immediately to a 60% win rate. So we need bans. I think it may be time to move on to 8 bans at the very least.
Champion Update Team VS The New Champion team is completely different and if one were to stop, it wouldn't increase the rate at which the other released content.
How was Rek'sai replaced by Ekko or Kindred? They are nothing alike.

Thats like asking how a chainsaw replaced a regular saw. They are quite different. One does the job much faster.

Where do you play Rek? In the jg? Top lane? When is the last time you saw her in a match. A new shinier jungle champ came along, a new shinier top laner came along. Ekko can be played Mid, Jg, and Top lane. Rek cant be played at all because she is weak compared to her betters. Superior champs that can fill her role got released, thats how she was replaced.

Just like new phones come out, and the new ones are better, the old ones just get left behind.
Yeah and we got a few more perma bans with the new mages. {{champion:90}}

Once League reaches a certain level of content, the only way to create a balanced competitive game will be to limit the available champions for competitive play.  If anyone is familiar with Magic the Gathering's pro tour, I believe LoL will do the same eventually.

Normal matches will have all content available. (Standard Format to continue the MTG analogy)
Ranked and competitive matches will be restricted to a certain pool of champions. (Type 2, in MTG analogy)

This is already done to a limited extent with patch changes.  Various champions get buffed/nerfed and the meta has micro changes respectively.  Also, I'm not advocating this change, it's just a hypothesis I have that addresses the growth vs. balance issue happening with LoL.

Please don't use examples about stuff you clearly know nothing about. Type 2 is not a format anymore, it was renamed Standard (so trying to call those 2 different things is laughably incorrect). And it's not just the pro tour. The majority of tournament magic is standard. It's the main supported constructed format. And the most played format in any organized play by a wide majority. The only thing that would compete with it is draft, which is a limited format. To put that in LOL terms, standard is comparable to summoners rift with draft being like aram.

What confuses me is that Riot always goes on about wanting people to use bans to prevent the enemy from countering them.  This never happens in low Elo because you usually can't put together a coherent team comp with clear counters before the ban phase, and rarely happens at the pro level because the pros know who they're fighting and ban to intentionally weaken the enemy team comp.  Allowing each person to ban would allow them to do a better job of preventing themselves from getting countered.

The other issue is that so many people are convinced that first pick has some huge advantage and use that as an excuse to not give them a ban, which is only partly true.  First pick gets to pick whoever the hell they want, but they also give the entire enemy team the opportunity to counter pick.
